questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman complains of progressive hearing loss, which aggravated during pregnancy. Pure tone audiometry reveals a Carhart's notch and she is diagnosed with otosclerosis. Identify the procedure done for this patient's condition.
questions.solution:
The above image shows a stapedotomy procedure performed in the middle ear.

It can be identified as a stapedotomy procedure by the following features in the image given:

  • The footplate of the stapes is not removed
  • The prosthesis is placed by creating a hole in the footplate of the stapes

Stapedotomy is the excision of the superstructure of stapes and drilling a hole in the footplate & placing a piston in the hole. It is done to bypass the immobile stapes using a piston which will take over the function of conducting sound.

Contraindications for Stapedotomy:

  • Only hearing ear
  • Positive Schwartze sign
  • Otitis externa
  • Meniere’s disease: can damage the inner ear while drilling a hole in the footplate
  • Young children
  • Professional athletes, pilots, construction workers, divers: Sudden change in pressure can displace the piston and cause vertigo.
  • Those who work in noisy surroundings: Surgery makes them more vulnerable to noise-induced hearing loss.

Otosclerosis is a primary disease of the bony labyrinth where foci of irregularly placed spongy bone replace part of the normally dense enchondral layer of the bony otic capsule. It is more commonly seen in females between 20-30 years of age and the hearing loss is aggravated during pregnancy and menopause.

Clinically, patients present with painless progressive bilateral conductive hearing loss and paracusis willisii (patient hears better in noisy surroundings as other people raise their voice to be heard). 

Tuning fork tests and audiometry will reveal the presence of conductive hearing loss. The bone conduction curve may show a dip, which is maximum at 2000Hz, known as Carhart’s notch.

The image shown below shows Carhart's notch.

Other options:

Options B and C: Stapes mobilization and Lempert’s fenestration operation are older procedures seldom performed these days.

Option D: Stapedectomy involves complete removal of the anterior and posterior portions of the footplate, leaving the membrane below the footplate intact. Now the oval window with its overlying membrane is covered with a piece of fascia and the prosthesis is placed over this.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient comes to the ENT outpatient department with complaints of difficulty in hearing in the left ear. Rinne’s test shows bone conduction is better than air conduction. Weber test shows lateralization towards the left ear. The absolute bone conduction test is normal. What will be the inference of Schwabach's test in this patient?

choices.text: Lengthened as compared to the examiner
Shortened as compared to the examiner
Same as compared to the examiner
Difficult to interpret with the given data

questions.solution:
The given inferences of various tests are suggestive of conductive deafness and Schwabach’s test is lengthened in conductive deafness.

TUNING FORK TESTS:
I) Rinne’s test:

A vibrating tuning fork is placed on the patient’s mastoid and when he stops hearing, it is brought beside the meatus. If he still hears, air conduction is better than bone conduction.

  • Positive - when the air conduction (AC) is longer or louder than bone conduction (BC). Seen in normal persons and persons with sensory-neural deafness.
  • Negative - when the bone conduction is better than air conduction. Seen in patients with conductive deafness.

II) Weber test:

A vibrating tuning fork is placed in the middle of the forehead or the vertex and the patient is asked in which ear the sound is heard.

  • Normal - heard equally in both ears
  • Conductive deafness - lateralized to the worse ear
  • Sensorineural deafness - lateralized to the better ear.

III) Absolute Bone Conduction test:

Here, the patient’s bone conduction is compared with that of the examiner. The external auditory meatus of both the patient and the examiner should be occluded ( by pressing the tragus inwards) to prevent the ambient noise from entering through the AC route.

  • Normal - same as the examiner.
  • Conductive deafness - same as the examiner.
  • Sensorineural deafness - reduced than that of the examiner.

IV) Schwabach test:

Here, again the bone conduction of the patient is compared with that of the normal hearing person(examiner) but the meatus is not occluded. 

  • Normal - same as the examiner
  • Conductive deafness - lengthened as compared to the examiner
  • Sensorineural deafness - shortened as compared to the examiner

     

Related Pearl: Tuning fork tests

Tests Normal
Conductive 
loss
Sensorineural
loss
Rinne AC > BC (Rinne +) BC > AC (Rinne -) AC > BC (Rinne +)
Weber Center Lateralized to the affected ear Lateralized to the normal ear
Absolute bone conduction Normal Normal Reduced
Schwabach Normal Lengthened Shortened
Bing Positive Negative Positive
Gelle Positive Negative (ossicular lesions) Positive

AC- Air conduction; BC- Bone conduction.

questions.text:
Which of the following are the objective tests for the hearing?
  1. Brainstem-evoked response audiometry
  2. Otoacoustic emissions
  3. Pure tone audiometry 
  4. Tympanometry
questions.solution:
Brainstem-evoked response audiometry (BERA), otoacoustic emissions (OAE), and tympanometry are objective tests for hearing. 

The objective tests of hearing are:

  • Evoked response audiometry
    • Electrocochleography
    • Auditory brainstem response
  • Otoacoustic emissions
  • Impedance audiometry
    • Tympanometry
    • Acoustic reflex measurements

Objective tests in ENT are diagnostic procedures that provide measurable, examiner-independent results. 

Brainstem-evoked response audiometry (BERA) or Auditory brainstem response (ABR) is an objective test that records electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway. It elicits brainstem responses to auditory stimulation. Click stimuli or tone bursts lead to the generation of electrical potentials which are picked up from surface electrodes on the vertex.

Otoacoustic emissions (OAEs) refer to an objective test that records the low-intensity sounds produced by the outer hair cells of a normal cochlea. It can be elicited by a microphone in the external auditory canal and is then analyzed by a computer. They test the function of the cochlea. They are used to test hearing in neonates, and sedated/unconscious patients, and to differentiate cochlear from retro-cochlear hearing loss. 

Tympanometry is a component of impedance audiometry. It is an objective test of the middle ear and eustachian tube functions (conductive compartment of hearing). Here, the compliance of the tympanic membrane, i.e., how much it moves to the pressure differentials applied from the external ear is measured. This is plotted on a graph, to obtain a tympanogram. 

Note- Pure tone audiometry is a subjective test for hearing as it relies on the patient's responses to pure tone stimuli. Other examples of subjective tests include:

  • Tuning fork tests
  • Speech audiometry

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

Symbols used in pure tone audiometry:

 

Disease Findings in PTA audiogram
Conductive hearing loss AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present
Sensorineural hearing loss Both AC and BC are abnormal and no air-Bone gap
Mixed hearing loss Both AC and BC abnormal and air-bone gap present
Presbycusis, ototoxicity, noise-induced hearing loss (higher frequencies affected first) Downsloping or descending audiogram 
Early stages of Meniere's disease (lower frequencies affected first) Upsloping or ascending audiogram
Congenital hearing loss and cochlear otosclerosis (mid-frequency hearing loss) U-shaped or trough-shaped or cookie bite shaped audiogram
Early cases of noise-induced hearing loss

Acoustic dip - characteristic dip in both AC and BC at 4000 Hz
Otosclerosis  Carhart's notch- dip at 2000 Hz in BC curve

 

Related Pearl: BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) or ABR (Auditory Brainstem Response)

It is an objective test that records electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway.

Normally, 7 waves are produced in the first 10ms. 

  • Wave I – distal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave II –proximal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave III – cochlear nucleus
  • Wave IV – superior olivary complex
  • Wave V – lateral lemniscus
  • Wave VI – inferior colliculus
  • Wave VII - medial geniculate body

Findings:

  • Conductive or cochlear pathology- delayed wave-I but inter-peak latency of I-V is normal
  • Retrocochlear pathology- wave-I present, rest of the waves absent
  • Acoustic neuroma or vestibular schwannoma- increased inter-peak latency of wave I-V and increased inter-aural latency of wave V > 0.2ms.

Uses:

  • To objectively find hearing threshold- wave-V appears 10dB above the hearing level obtained through PTA
  • Best audiometric test for:
    • Confirming hearing loss in infants
    • Diagnosing acoustic neuroma
    • Differentiating cochlear and retro-cochlear hearing loss
    • Diagnosing non-organic hearing loss.

Related Pearl: OAEs - Otoacoustic emissions

It is an objective test that records the low-intensity sounds produced by the outer hair cells of a normal cochlea.

It is of two types:

  • Spontaneous type- it is generated spontaneously and is present in 50% of normal individuals.
  • Evoked types- also called Kemp echoes or cochlear echoes, are generated in response to sound stimulus and found in all individuals with normal hearing. The two subtypes are transient evoked and distortion product.

The applications are as follows:

  • Best audiometric test for screening in neonates, infants, and small children for deafness due to inner ear causes.
  • Helps to differentiate cochlear and retrocochlear hearing loss- normal OAE indicates normal cochlea and hence retrocochlear pathology in a patient with sensorineural deafness.
  • Early detection of noise-induced hearing loss- since it is generated by outer hair cells that are prone to damage by noise trauma.

questions.text:
A 69-year-old diabetic patient has come to you with excruciating right ear pain and right-sided facial palsy. Otoscopic examination of the ear shows granulations on the floor of the external auditory canal. Choose the correct statements regarding this condition.
  1. It is a malignant condition.
  2. It can occur in immunocompromised patients.
  3. Technetium 99 scan is used to monitor the disease.
  4. Gallium-67 scan is useful in the follow-up of the patient.
  5. Prolonged antibiotic therapy is given.
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of an elderly diabetic patient with excruciating ear pain, facial palsy, and granulations on the floor of the external auditory canal points toward the diagnosis of malignant otitis externa. The correct statements are 2, 4 and 5.

Malignant otitis externa is an infective condition (not malignant). Technetium 99 scan is not used to monitor the disease. 

It is an inflammatory condition caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa in elderly diabetics and immunocompromised patients. It is characterised by excruciating ear pain, profuse discharge and granulations on the floor of the external ear canal.

Necrosis of bone aids in the spread of infection. Infection may spread to the skull base and jugular foramen causing multiple cranial nerve palsies. Facial paralysis is the most common nerve palsy seen.

Gallium-67 scan is useful in the diagnosis and follow-up of the patient. It can be repeated every 3 weeks to monitor the disease and response to treatment. Technetium 99 bone scan reveals bone infection, but the test remains positive for a year or so and cannot be used to monitor the disease.

Treatment includes:

  • Control of diabetes.
  • Toilet of the ear canal. Remove discharge, debris and granulations or at dead tissue or bone.
  • Antibiotic treatment against P. aeruginosa for 6-8 weeks or more. If the patient is not responsive, treatment should be based on culture and sensitivity of ear discharge.

Antibiotics which are usually effective against pseudomonas aeroginosa are:

  • Gentamicin combined with ticarcillin (IV)
  • Third-generation cephalosporins (IV) e.g. ceftriaxone, ceftazidime along with an aminoglycoside
  • Fluoroquinolones (ciprofloxacin, ofloxacin and levofloxacin) combined with rifampin (Oral)

questions.text:
Match the following signs and the diseases in which they occur.
Signs Diseases
  1. Hennebert's sign
  2. Schwartz sign
  3. Hitzelberger sign
  4. Bryce's sign
  1. Laryngocele
  2. Congenital syphilis
  3. Otosclerosis
  4. Acoustic neuroma
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pair is 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a.

1 - Hennebert's sign in congenital syphilis

Hennebert's sign is a positive fistula sign (nystagmus occurring on applying positive and negative pressure in the external auditory canal) in the absence of a fistula seen in congenital syphilis due to the formation of adhesions between stapes footplate and saccule. It is also seen in a few cases of Meniere's disease.

This is not to be confused with Hennebert's phenomenon which is disequilibrium following nose blowing or lifting a heavy object. It is seen in the perilymph fistula.

2 - Schwartz sign in otosclerosis

A pink or reddish hue seen on the promontory through the tympanic membrane is called the Schwartz sign. It is seen in active otosclerosis.

The image below shows the Schwartz sign.

3 - Hitzelberger sign in acoustic neuroma

Numbness in the posterosuperior meatal wall of the external auditory canal (supplied by the VII cranial nerve) is known as the Hitzelberger sign. It is due to the involvement of the VII cranial nerve in acoustic neuroma.

4 - Bryce's sign in laryngocele

The gurgling sound produced on pressing the swelling in the laryngocele is known as Bryce's sign.

questions.text: A patient with middle ear fluid accumulation is tested using tympanometry. What is the expected tympanogram finding seen in this case?

choices.text: Compliance is high at or near ambient air pressure
Compliance is lower at or near ambient air pressure
Maximum compliance occurs with negative pressure

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of middle ear fluid accumulation, the expected tympanogram finding would be a flat or dome-shaped graph.

Tympanometry: It is used in evaluating the status of the middle ear and the functioning of the eustachian tube.

Principle: When a sound wave strikes the tympanic membrane, some of the sound energy is absorbed while the rest is reflected. A stiffer tympanic membrane would reflect more sound energy than a compliant one.

By changing the pressures in a sealed external auditory canal and then measuring the reflected sound energy, it is possible to find the compliance or stiffness of the tympano-ossicular system and thus find the healthy or diseased status of the middle ear.

Tympanometry is also used in evaluating the patency of the grommet inserted in the tympanic membrane for treating serous otitis media.

By charting the compliance of the tympano-ossicular system against various pressure changes, different types of graphs called tympanograms are obtained. They are as follows:

The image given below shows impedance audiometry. Impedance audiometry consists of tympanometry and acoustic reflex measurements.

Tympanometry equipment consists of a probe that snugly fits into the external auditory canal and has three channels.

  • To deliver a tone of 220Hz
  • To absorb reflected sound
  • To change the pressure in the external auditory canal

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: A patient is planned to undergo tympanoplasty. In which type of tympanoplasty is the graft placed in contact with the structure marked in the given image, according to Wullstein's classification?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the given image is the incus. Type II tympanoplasty is performed when the malleus is eroded due to middle ear disease and the graft is placed on the incus.

The incus is one of the three ossicles of the middle ear. It has a body and a short process, both of which lie in the attic and can be identified by the long process that hangs vertically and attaches to the head of the stapes.

Tympanoplasty is the surgical reconstruction to correct damage in the middle ear and restore the integrity of the tympanic membrane. It involves ossiculoplasty (reconstruction of the ossicular chain) with or without myringoplasty.

The main objective of the procedure is the eradication of middle ear disease with the reconstruction of the tympanic membrane and ossicles.

Myringoplasty is the term given for the closure of perforation of pars tensa of tympanic membrane done to check repeated infections from the external ear.

Type Defect and repair
Type I Perforation of tympanic membrane which is repaired with a graft (myringoplasty)
Type II Perforation of tympanic membrane with erosion of malleus. The graft is placed on the incus or remnant of the malleus.
Type III Malleus and incus are absent. The graft is placed directly on the stapes head (myringostapediopexy)
Type IV Only the footplate of stapes is present. The graft is placed between the oval and round windows on the stapes footplate
Type V The stapes footplate is fixed but the round window is functioning. The graft is placed in contact with a new window created on the fenestra in the horizontal semicircular canal

 

Related Pearl: Zollner and Wullstein’s classification/ Types of tympanoplasty

Type Findings Procedure
Graft placed over
Type I (or) Myringoplasty All ossicles are intact Over/ under remnant TM over the handle of malleus
Type II Malleus eroded Over the remnant malleus/ incus
Type III (or) Columella (or) Myringostapediopexy Malleus & incus absent Over stapes superstructure
Type IV (or) Cavum minor All ossicles eroded Over ET and the round window, leaving mobile footplate expose
Type V (or) Fenestration surgery Fixed footplate An opening made in the lateral semicircular canal (an alternative pathway)
Type VI (or) Sono-Inversion --- The round window is left exposed and receives sound and the oval window is covered (reversed pathway)

Type III is called columella because it resembles the middle ear of birds. They have a single ossicle. Type VI is not part of the original Zollner-Wullstein classification. It is a recent addition.

Image showing different types of tympanoplasty:

SCC: Semicircular canal.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy who was treated for acute otitis media 2 weeks back presents with fever,  and pain behind his right ear. On examination, tenderness is present over the mastoid and the pinna is pushed anteriorly suggesting acute mastoiditis. A fluctuant swelling is present between the tip of the mastoid and the angle of the jaw. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along is most likely suggestive of the diagnosis of Bezold's abscess.

Bezold abscess is defined as a complication of acute coalescent mastoiditis and is formed when pus breaks inferiorly, through the thin medial aspect of the tip of the mastoid and collects in the upper part of the neck, most commonly into the sheath of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. The abscess can also take any of the following locations: 

  • Deep to the sternocleidomastoid
  • Along the posterior belly of the digastric presenting as a swelling in the tip of the mastoid or the angle of the jaw
  • The upper part of the posterior triangle
  • Parapharyngeal space
  • Along with the carotid vessels.

Treatment:

  1. Cortical mastoidectomy for coalescent mastoiditis
  2. Drainage of the abscess in the neck with insertion of a drain through a separate incision
  3. IV antibiotics

Other options:

Option A: Zygomatic abscess forms due to infection of the zygomatic air cells. It is situated at the posterior root of the zygoma.  Patients present with swelling in front and above the pinna with associated edema over the upper eyelid. Here the pus collects either superficial or deep to the temporalis muscle.

Option C: Luc abscess is defined as a subperiosteal temporal abscess. It develops following the spread of infection from the middle ear along the external auditory meatus, directly, to the temporal region. Swelling is present in the deep part of the bony meatus. 

Option D: Citelli’s abscess is formed posterior to the mastoid, occupying a position more towards the occipital bone. It is also considered an abscess of the digastric triangle. In any case, a diagnosis of Bezold abscess is more appropriate for this patient owing to the location of the abscess.

questions.text: A patient comes with a complaint of vertigo in a certain head position. She denies any ear fullness or hearing loss. A Dix-Hallpike maneuver confirms the diagnosis and an Epley's maneuver is performed to treat her condition. The symptoms are relieved due to the repositioning of otoconial debris from?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient with vertigo and a positive Dix-Hallpike test is suggestive of benign positional paroxysmal vertigo (BPPV). The otoconial debris are repositioned from the posterior semicircular canal to the utricle to relieve the symptoms of BPPV.

BPPV is one of the common causes of recurrent vertigo, and the episodes are brief (<1min) and are always provoked by changes in head position. The attacks are caused by free-floating calcium carbonate crystals usually dislodged from the posterior canal. 

A positive Dix-Hallpike maneuver confirms the diagnosis of BPPV. It is due to otoconial debris getting into the posterior semicircular canal from the utricle. The patient complains of vertigo on moving or tilting the head to the affected side. In up to 90 percent of the patients, it can be relieved by administering a therapeutic Epley's maneuver on the affected side.

The Epley's maneuver consists of five positions:

  Head and neck Body position
Position 1 Head turned 45°  to lie down in a head-hanging position
Position 2 Head turned with
affected ear up		 -
Position 3 The whole body and head rotated away from the affected ear in a face-down position  
Position 4 Head still turned to unaffected side by 45° Brought to sitting position
Position 5 Head turned forward with chin brought down 20° -

questions.text: A patient with impacted wax develops a severe cough while performing the following procedure on him. This is due to stimulation of which of the following nerve?
questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the image is syringing, usually done for the removal of impacted wax. Reflex cough due to stimulation of the auricular branch of vagus can occur during this procedure.

Wax is made up of sebaceous and ceruminous gland secretions, hair, desquamated epithelial debris, keratin, and dirt. Factors contributing to the accumulation and impaction of excess wax may be a narrow, tortuous external canal, stiff ear, or obstructive lesions in the canal.

Patients with impacted wax may present with impaired hearing, tinnitus or giddiness. Long-standing impacted wax may ulcerate meatal skin and result in the formation of a wax granuloma.

Wax removal is achieved through syringing or other instrumental manipulation. Hard impacted mass may require prior softening with wax solvents in some cases.

The patient is seated, with the ear to be syringed facing the examiner. The patient wears a kidney tray over his or her shoulder and to collect the return fluid, the patient's head is tilted over the tray. A stream of water from the syringe is directed along the posterosuperior wall of the meatus as the pinna is pulled upwards and backward. The ear canal and tympanic membrane must be inspected and dried with a pledget of cotton at the end of the procedure.

Complications of syringing:

  • Vertigo– caloric stimulation of lateral semicircular canal if water is too hot or too cold
  • Rupture of the tympanic membrane
  • Reactivation of quiescent otitis media, if there is pre-existing perforation

Contraindications for syringing:

  • Presence of ear infection, tympanic membrane perforation
  • Presence of grommet or history of ear surgery.

questions.text: A male patient is brought into the emergency after a road traffic accident in which he has sustained injuries on the face. You note excessive mobility of the maxilla but no mobility of the nose. A CT scan reveals a fracture line passing through the lower part of the nasal septum, maxillary antrum, and pterygoid plates. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Le-Fort I fracture of the maxilla. 

Le Fort Type 1 fractures generally occur on the horizontal plane at the level of the nose base. It is caused due to downward directed force onto the lower part of the maxillary rim.

It involves the three walls of the maxillary sinus as well as the pterygoid processes, extending around the maxillary antrum, nasal septum, and pterygoid plate. This leads to the separation of the palate and face. There is no involvement of the glabella or zygoma in this case. 

Clinically, patients present with swollen upper lip, anterior open bite malocclusion, maxillary buccal vestibule, palate ecchymosis, and mobility of the maxilla.

Diagnosis is made with X-rays (Water's view, posteroanterior view, and lateral view) and CT scan. They help to understand the full extent of injuries. 

Treatment requires fixation of the maxillary fractures which can be achieved by interdental wiring, and intermaxillary wiring using arch bars. Open reduction and interosseous wiring may be required in zygomatic fractures.

Related Pearl: Le-Fort's classification of Maxillary Fracture

Le-Fort I is a transverse fracture of the maxilla
  • Fracture line passes through the lower part of nasal septum, maxillary antra and the pterygoid plates
  • It separates palate from the rest of the face leading to floating teeth or palate
  • Also called Guerin’s fracture. 
Le-Fort II is a pyramidal fracture
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, lacrimal bone, floor of the orbit, upper part of the maxillary sinus and pterygoid plates
  • X-ray or CT appears like hanging maxilla
  • It is associated with CSF rhinorrhea.
Le-Fort III is craniofacial dysjunction i.e., facial skeleton completely disconnected from its cranial attachment
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, ethmo-frontal junction, superior orbital fissure, lateral wall of the orbit, fronto-zygomatic and temporo-zygomatic sutures and the upper part of pterygoid plates
  • It is also associated with CSF rhinorrhea.

questions.text: A patient with complaints of nasal obstruction and nasal discharge was diagnosed to be a case of an antrochoanal polyp. All of the following statements are true about the condition except
questions.solution:
All of the above statements about the antrochoanal polyp are true except it is bilateral.

Antrochoanal polyp is a type of non-neoplastic nasal polypoidal masses of edematous nasal or sinus mucosa. It arises from the mucosa of the maxillary antrum near its accessory ostium, comes out of it, and grows in the choana and nasal cavity. It is usually single and unilateral which are more commonly seen in children and young adults. 

It has 3 parts namely

  • Thin antral stalk,
  • Round and globular choanal part, and
  • Flat nasal part.

The clinical features include unilateral nasal obstruction, mucoid nasal discharge, and a hyponasal voice.

Anterior rhinoscopy may miss the antrochoanal polyp when it starts to grow posteriorly. A large polyp may protrude from the nasal cavity and may appear pink and congested. It is soft and can be moved with a probe. Posterior rhinoscopy may reveal a globular mass filling the choana and hanging down behind the soft palate.

Diagnosis is made by radiograph of the paranasal sinuses reveals opacity of the involved antrum. Non-contrast CT scan reveals the extent of the polyp. Endoscopic examination reveals the antrochoanal polyp hidden posteriorly in the nasal cavity.

Endoscopic sinus surgery is the treatment of choice. Recurrence is uncommon after the complete removal of the polyp.

Related Pearl: Antrochoanal Polyp

  • Main etiological factors: Infection and allergy
  • Usually affects children
  • Site of origin: Mucosa of the maxillary antrum
  • Clinical features:
    • Usually single and unilateral
    • Unilateral nasal obstruction which becomes bilateral when it grows posteriorly and obstructs opposite choana
    • Mucoid nasal discharge
    • Hyponasal voice
  • Findings:
    • Grows posteriorly and usually missed on anterior rhinoscopy
    • Posterior rhinoscopy: Globular mass filling the choana or nasopharynx
  • Investigation of choice: Nasal endoscopy. Shows nasal polyps that are pale, gelatinous and pedunculated
  • Treatment of choice: FESS

questions.text:
Match the following radiograph images with their views.
  1. Submentovertical view
  2. Caldwell view
  3. Water's view
  4. Towne's view
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pair is 1-c, 2-b, 3-d, 4-a.

1 c. Water's view
2 b. Caldwell view
3 d. Towne's view
4 a. Submentovertical view

Waters' view (also known as the Occipitomental view or nose-chin position) is a radiographic view, where an X-ray beam is angled at 37° to the orbitomeatal line. The rays are passed from behind the head and are perpendicular to the radiographic plate.

  • It is commonly used to get a better view of the maxillary sinuses.

Structures observed:

  • Maxillary sinuses
  • Frontal sinuses
  • Sphenoid sinus (through open mouth)
  • Zygoma
  • Zygomatic arch
  • Nasal bone

Caldwell's view (also known as the occipitofrontal view or nose-forehead position) is a radiographic view of the skull, where the X-ray plate is angled at 15° to the orbito-meatal line. The rays pass from behind the head and are perpendicular to the radiographic plate.

  • It is commonly used to get a better view of frontal sinuses.

Structures seen are: 

  • Frontal sinuses 
  • Ethmoid sinuses
  • Maxillary sinuses
  • Frontal process of the zygoma and the zygomatic process of the frontal bone
  • Superior margin of orbit and lamina papyracea
  • Superior orbital fissure
  • Foramen rotundum (inferolateral to superior orbital fissure)

The image below shows Caldwell's view 

Towne's view: 

It is taken with the patient in the supine position and lying on his back with the chin often depressed into the neck. The X-ray camera is angled at 30 degrees towards the feet so that the rays enter the head at the level of the hairline.

  • This is usually taken for acoustic neuroma and apical petrositis.
  • Bilateral petrous pyramids are visible in this view and hence can be compared.
Structures seen are:
  • Arcuate eminence and superior semicircular canal.
  • Mastoid antrum.
  • Internal auditory canal.
  • Tympanic cavity.
  • Cochlea.
  • External auditory canal.

The image below shows Towne's view 

Submentovertical view (also known as the basal view or Hirtz view) is taken with vertex near the film and X-ray beam projected at right angles to the film from the submental area.

 Structures seen are:
  • Sphenoid, posterior ethmoid, and maxillary sinuses (seen best in that order).
  • Zygoma.
  • Zygomatic arch.
  • Mandible along with coronoid and condyloid processes.
  • External auditory canal.
  • Middle ear cleft, i.e. mastoid cells, middle ear, and eustachian tube.
  • Internal auditory canal.

Related Pearl: Radiographic views of paranasal sinuses and mastoid

questions.text: A middle-aged patient presents with multiple nodules in the nasal mucosa. Biopsy from the nodules revealed the presence of Miculikz cells and Russell bodies. Which of the following is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the biopsy findings showing Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies are characteristic of rhinoscleroma.

Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis (Frisch bacillus).

Mikulicz cells are large foam cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated cytoplasm containing causative bacilli. Russell bodies are homogenous eosinophilic inclusion bodies found in the plasma cells due to the accumulation of immunoglobulins secreted by plasma cells. Histology also shows infiltration of submucosa with plasma cells, lymphocytes and eosinophils. 

The following image shows rhinoscleroma with Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies(marked in black arrows)

Rhinoscleroma starts in the nose and extends to the nasopharynx, oropharynx, subglottic larynx, trachea and bronchi. It has 3 stages:

  1. Atrophic stage– Crusting and foul-smelling nasal discharge similar to atrophic rhinitis.
  2. Granulomatous stage– Painless, non-ulcerative granulomatous nodules with subdermal infiltration giving the feel of a woody nose.
  3. Cicatricial stage – Fibrosis leading to stenosis of vestibule, pharynx and larynx. 

Treatment is done by the use of antibiotics streptomycin and tetracycline for 4 to 6 weeks. Steroids to reduce fibrosis. Surgical intervention may be required to restore the airway and correct the nasal deformity. Treatment is stopped only when two consecutive cultures from the biopsy are negative. 

Other options:

Option B: Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi characterised by multiple polypoidal growths. The biopsy shows several oval or round-shaped sporangia filled with spores bursting through the chitinous walls.

Option C: Lupus vulgaris is a low-grade tuberculosis infection characterised by chronic vestibulitis and perforation of the nasal septum. Biopsy shows tuberculous granuloma and caseous necrosis.

Option D: Granulomatosis with polyangitis is a chronic granulomatous disorder presenting with crusting, granulation and saddle deformity of the nose. Biopsy shows necrosis and ulceration of mucosa, epithelioid granuloma and necrotizing vasculitis of the vessels.

questions.text: A 30-year old patient comes to the hospital with complaints of blood-tinged nasal discharge. The anterior rhinoscopy shows a pink polypoidal mass in the right nose and the same is biopsied. The image given below is the histological slide of the specimen. Treatment of choice for this condition is?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the histopathology showing several sporangia is most likely suggestive of the diagnosis of rhinosporidiosis. Surgical management (Excision of the lesion with cauterisation of the base ), is the treatment of choice in rhinosporidiosis.

Rhinosporidiosis is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi. Patients clinically present with blood-tinged nasal discharge, and pink polypoidal mass in the nose.

Histopathology shows several sporangia, oval, or round in shape and filled with spores which may be seen bursting through its chitinous wall.

It is treated by completely excising the mass with a diathermy knife followed by cauterization of the base.

Related Pearl: Rhinosporidiosis

  • It is a chronic granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi which is recently reclassified as a member of the protistan Mesomycetozoa
  • It is more common in the southern states of India
  • It affects immunocompetent individuals
  • Most commonly a waterborne disease
  • Clinical features: Blood tinged nasal discharge, frank epistaxis, nasal stuffiness
  • Findings: 
    • Leafy, polypoidal mass, pink to purple in color and attached to the nasal septum or lateral wall
    • Sometimes, it extends into the nasopharynx and may hang behind the soft palate
    • The mass is very vascular and bleeds easily on touch
    • Its surface is studded with white dots representing the sporangia
  • Diagnosis: Biopsy which shows sporangia

Histologic section showing sporangium (arrow) which is fully packed with immature sporoblasts at the periphery and mature ones at the center

Treatment: Complete excision of the mass with diathermy knife and cauterization of its base. Recurrence may occur after surgical excision. Dapsone is also used.

questions.text: A patient presents with bilateral nasal obstruction. On anterior rhinoscopy, multiple smooth pale glistening masses are found bilaterally suggestive of ethmoidal polyps. The surgeon plans functional endoscopic sinus surgery to remove them. Which of the following structures shown in the image given below is removed during infundibulotomy?
questions.solution:
The image above shows the computed tomography (CT) scan of the ostiomeatal complex in the coronal plane. The structure marked as 1 is the uncinate process which is removed in infundibulotomy.

Infundibulotomy, also known as uncinectomy, is the first surgical step in functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS). FESS is the treatment of choice for ethmoidal polyps, which this patient has.

The structure marked as 2 is the ethmoidal bulla, and is removed in bullectomy.

The structure marked as 3 is the middle turbinate

The structure marked as 4 is the medial wall of the maxillary sinus.

Important steps in FESS:

  1. Uncinectomy or Infundibulotomy
  2. Identification and enlargement of the maxillary ostium
  3. Bullectomy
  4. Penetration of basal lamella and posterior ethmoidal cells
  5. Clearance of frontal recess and frontal sinusotomy
  6. Sphenoidotomy
  7. Nasal packing

Indications of FESS:

  • Chronic bacterial sinusitis refractory to medical treatment.
  • Recurrent acute bacterial sinusitis.
  • Polypoid rhinosinusitis.
  • Fungal sinusitis with fungal ball.
  • Antrochoanal polyp.
  • Mucocele of frontoethmoid or sphenoid sinus.
  • Endoscopic septoplasty.
  • Epistaxis control by endoscopic cautery.
  • Foreign body removal from the nose or sinus.

Related Pearl: Ethmoidal polyps

  • Main etiological factor is allergy
  • Usually affects the middle-aged
  • Site of origin: Lateral wall of the nose
  • Clinical features: Nasal stuffiness, headache (due to sinusitis), sneezing, watery nasal discharge, anosmia/ hyposmia, mass protruding from the nasal cavity
  • Findings:
    • Anterior rhinoscopy: Multiple, bilateral polypi that are smooth, glistening, grape-like masses often pale in color
    • They may be sessile or pedunculated, insensitive to probing and do not bleed on touch
  • Investigation of choice: NCCT
  • Treatment of choice: FESS

questions.text: A 40-year-old male fell down while climbing the stairs. He presented with complaints of fluid dripping from his nose, which he couldn't sniff back. The nasal discharge has the following appearance on tissue paper.  Which investigation should be ordered to localize the lesion?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the image showing a double target sign are suggestive of CSF rhinorrhea and high-resolution computerized tomography (HRCT) is the investigation of choice for localizing the site of the leak in this condition.

Double ring sign or halo sign or target sign - when cerebrospinal fluid mixed with blood is collected on a piece of filter paper, it will show a central red spot (blood) and a peripheral lighter halo.

CSF rhinorrhea refers to the leakage of clear or blood-tinged CSF into the nose. Fracture of the cribriform plate of the ethmoid is the most common cause of this. Other causes include accidental or surgical trauma, infection and inflammation of the sinuses, neoplasms, and congenital lesions associated with skull base defects or may occur spontaneously.

Early cases of post-traumatic CSF rhinorrhea are managed conservatively by placing the patient in a semi-sitting position. Blowing of the nose, sneezing, and straining should be avoided. Prophylactic antibiotics can be administered to prevent meningitis. Persistent cases may be treated surgically by the intracranial or nasal endoscopic approach. The nasal endoscopic approach is useful for leaks from the frontal sinus, cribriform plate, and ethmoid or sphenoid sinuses.

Other options:

Option A: Gadolinium-enhanced MRI is the investigation of choice in glomus tumours, carotid body tumours and acoustic neuromas. MRI can be used to localize the lesion in CSF rhinorrhea but the CSF leak should be actively present at the time of the scan.

Option C: Beta-2 transferrin protein detection by electrophoresis is a sensitive and specific test for detecting CSF rhinorrhea. Since it is absent in nasal secretions it helps to differentiate CSF from nasal secretions. It is also present in aqueous humor and perilymph. However, it cannot be used to localize the site of the leak.

Option D: CT cisternogram is done in cases where beta-2 transferrin detection is not available. It involves an intrathecal injection of iohexol followed by a CT scan. It is not preferred nowadays.

Note: Beta trace protein is another protein that is secreted by meninges and choroid plexus and is specific for CSF, but testing facilities are not widely available. An intrathecal fluorescein study may be performed preoperatively or intraoperatively to confirm the site of the defect.

Related Pearl: Features of CSF rhinorrhea

  • Reservoir sign - In CSF rhinorrhea, the fluid which had collected in the sinuses, particularly sphenoid, empties into the nose.
  • Double ring sign or halo sign or target sign - CSF is mixed with blood and collected on a piece of filter paper. It shows a central red spot (blood) and a peripheral lighter halo.

The image below shows the double ring sign in CSF rhinorrhoea:

  • CSF can’t be sniffed back.
  • CSF doesn’t stiffen the handkerchief.

 

Note: The repeated reappearance of pus immediately after cleaning, in the external auditory canal of patients with acute mastoiditis/coalescent mastoiditis is also referred to as Reservoir sign.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presented to you with complaints of pain over the nose after falling from height. On examination, there is a fracture of the nasal septum. Which of the following instruments would you use during the surgery for this patient?
questions.solution:
The instrument used in the above scenario is the Asch forceps (image 2). It is mainly used to reduce a nasal septum fracture.

Other options:

Option A: Luc’s forceps (image 1) is used in Caldwell Luc operation, submucous resection, and polypectomy.

Option C: Tilley’s forceps (image 3) is used in nasal packing in the epistaxis.

Option D: Citelli’s forceps (image 4) is used for bone punch.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with unilateral nasal obstruction. To check for patency of the nasal valve, a Cottle test is performed. In which of the following cases is the test positive?
questions.solution:
Cottle test is positive in patients with a deviated nasal septum. It is used to assess the patency of the nasal valve and when positive, it indicates the abnormality in the vestibular component of the nasal valve.

In this test, the cheek is drawn laterally while the patient breathes quietly. If the nasal airway improves and the obstruction is relieved on the test side, the test is positive and indicates the surgery will be useful and the patient can be taken up for surgery.

The nasal valve area is the narrowest portion of the nasal passage. It is bounded medially by the nasal septum, superiorly and laterally by the caudal margin of the upper lateral cartilage, inferiorly by the floor of the piriform aperture and the nasal valve is the specific slit-like segment between the caudal margin of the upper lateral cartilage and the septum.

Conditions with a positive Cottle test:

  • Deviated nasal septum
  • Collapsed nasal valve - causes snoring and sleep apnoea
  • Valve stenosis

The below image depicts Cottle's test

The deviated nasal septum (DNS) may be caused by two main factors, trauma or developmental errors in addition to being dependent on racial and hereditary factors. Patients present with nasal obstruction, headache, sinusitis, and epistaxis and may manifest an external deformity as well.

Anatomically, DNS can be of various types

  • Anterior dislocation or the septal cartilage into one of the chambers
  • C-shaped deformity: the chamber on the concave side of the nasal septum will be wider and show compensatory hypertrophy of turbinates
  • S-shaped deformity: may cause bilateral nasal obstruction
  • Spur: a shelf-like projection often found at the junction of bone and cartilage
  • Thickening: thickening of a septum due to an organised hematoma may also cause obstruction

Treatment of DNS depends on the severity of symptoms. If asymptomatic, no treatment is required. When DNS causes a mechanical obstruction, submucosal resection or septoplasty (more conservative) may be done.

Other options:

Epistaxis refers to bleeding into the nasal cavity and most commonly occurs in the little's area in the anteroinferior part of the nasal septum. Cottle test to relieve nasal obstruction has no role here. Trotter's method is used as a first aid to arrest bleeding from the little's area.

Atrophic rhinitis refers to chronic inflammation of the nose with atrophy of nasal mucosa. The patients may present with nasal obstruction due to the crusting filling the roomy nasal cavity. Removal of the crust may relieve the obstruction but has the risk of bleeding.

The nasal polyp occurs due to edematous nasal mucosa. It can be an antrochoanal polyp arising from the mucosa of the maxillary antrum or an ethmoidal polyp arising from the middle meatus in the lateral wall of the nose. These polyps appear as globular mass and can be differentiated from turbinate hypertrophy by a probe test. Nasal obstruction resulting from polyps get resolved by conservative or surgical management.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of septal perforation?
questions.solution:
Trauma is the most common cause of septal perforation.

Causes of septal perforation:

  • Trauma - nasal surgery, nose picking, septal cauterization, nasal packing, septal hematoma, foreign bodies
  • Surface irritants - cocaine, heroin, decongestant nasal sprays
  • Infections - syphilis, typhoid, tuberculosis, lepromatous leprosy, rhinosporidiosis, rhinoscleroma, aspergillosis
  • Neoplastic - melanoma, SCC, adenocarcinoma, lymphoma
  • Inflammatory - sarcoidosis, Crohn's disease, RA, Granulomatosis with polyangitis

Small anterior perforations may present with a whistling sound during respiration. Large perforations may obstruct the nose or even bleed due to the formation of crusts.

Treatment depends on the cause. Small asymptomatic perforations can be closed by plastic flaps. In larger perforations treatment is aimed at keeping the nose crust-free using nasal douches and bland ointments.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is inconsistent with nasopharyngeal carcinoma?

choices.text: Most common site of origin is the fossa of Rosenmuller
CN V involvement leads to reduced corneal reflex
Hearing loss is the most common presentation
Tumor can invade the orbit and cause exophthalmos

questions.solution:
The statement ‘hearing loss is the most common presentation’ is inconsistent with nasopharyngeal carcinoma. 

The most common presenting symptom is cervical lymphadenopathy, occurring in 60-90% of cases. 

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is a malignant tumor of the nasopharynx. The theories for etiology include genetics, infection with Epstein-Barr virus, air pollution, and smoking.

It has three types -

  1. Keratinizing carcinoma
  2. Nonkeratinizing differentiated carcinoma
  3. Nonkeratinizing undifferentiated carcinoma. 

The most common site of origin of nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of Rosenmuller (Option A). From here, it can spread extensively in any direction locally. It also can spread lymphatically to the cervical, retropharyngeal, or parapharyngeal lymph nodes. 

Trotter's triad consists of ipsilateral conductive hearing loss (eustachian tube blockage), trigeminal neuralgia of the mandibular division, and palatal asymmetry due to invasion of levator palatini muscles may be seen. This triad occurs in malignant tumors of the lateral nasopharyngeal wall due to extensive invasion. 

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma presents with the following symptoms:

  • Nasal - obstruction, discharge, rhinolalia clausa, epistaxis
  • Ear - eustachian tube obstruction leading to conductive hearing loss or recurrent otitis media. 
  • Ophthalmoneurologic - all the cranial nerves (CN) may be involved. 
    • CN VI - squint and diplopia, the most common cranial nerve involved
    • CN III, IV, VI, - ophthalmoplegia
    • CN V - reduced corneal reflex (Option B)
    • CN II - exophthalmos (Option D)
    • CN IX, X, XI - jugular foramen syndrome
    • Horner’s syndrome
  • Cervical lymph node metastasis
  • Distant metastasis to the bone, liver, and lung. 

Diagnosis is made by high resolution, contrast-enhanced CT of the neck.

The treatment of choice is radiotherapy. Stage I and II can be treated with radiotherapy alone, while higher stages require combination treatment with radiotherapy and chemotherapy.

questions.text: A male patient presents with a sore throat and difficulty swallowing for 2 days. On oropharyngeal examination, a grey-white membrane is observed over the tonsils. All of the following are differential diagnoses for membrane over the tonsils except
questions.solution:
All the above-mentioned options are the differential diagnosis for membrane over the tonsils except Ludwig’s angina. Ludwig’s angina is the infection of the submandibular space.

The differential diagnosis for grey membrane over the tonsils includes the following

  • Streptococcus & other pyogenic organisms
  • Diphtheria
  • Infectious mononucleosis
  • Vincent’s angina
  • Leukemia
  • Candida
  • Agranulocytosis
  • Malignancy
  • Aphthous ulcer
  • Traumatic ulcer

 The image given below shows acute tonsillitis presenting with a membrane over the tonsil.

The image given below shows pseudomembrane over tonsil typically seen in diphtheria.

The image given below shows oral candidiasis.

Ludwig’s angina is the infection of the submandibular space. The space lies between the mucous membrane of the floor of the mouth and tongue on one side and the superficial layer of deep cervical fascia extending between the hyoid bone and mandible on the other. It is most commonly caused by dental infections

Clinically, patients present with difficulty in swallowing (odynophagia) and trismus. On examination, the floor of the mouth is swollen and the tongue is pushed up and back. The submental and submandibular space becomes swollen, tender, and has a woody-hard feel.

Complications of this condition include the spread of infection to the parapharyngeal space, retropharyngeal space, and the mediastinum, airway obstruction, septicemia, and aspiration pneumonia.

questions.text: A patient with bilateral abductor paralysis is admitted to the intensive care unit. In order to relieve the respiratory obstruction, a tracheostomy is being performed. Which of the following is not an immediate complication of this procedure?
questions.solution:
Tracheal stenosis, due to tracheal ulceration and infection, is a late complication of tracheostomy and does not occur immediately.

A tracheostomy is a procedure where an opening is made in the anterior wall of the trachea and it is converted into a stoma on the skin surface. It is primarily indicated when there is respiratory obstruction, secretions, or respiratory insufficiency. It is also indicated in an intubated patient after 2-3 weeks to avoid subglottic stenosis.

Complications of tracheostomy:

Immediate

(at the time of operation)

Intermediate

(during first few hours or days)

Late

(after chronic use for weeks or months)
  1. Primary hemorrhage
  2. Apnoea due to sudden washout of CO2
  3. Pneumothorax due to injury to apical pleura
  4. Injury to recurrent laryngeal nerves
  5. Aspiration of blood
  6. Injury to esopgahus
  1. Reactionary or secondary hemorrhage.
  2. Displacement of the tube.
  3. Blocking of the tube.
  4. Subcutaneous emphysema.
  5. Tracheitis and tracheobronchitis.
  6. Atelectasis and lung abscess.
  7. Local wound infection and granulations.
  1. Laryngeal stenosis.
  2. Tracheal stenosis
  3. Tracheo-oesophageal fistula
  4. Problems of decannulation.
  5. Persistent tracheocutaneous fistula.
  6. Keloid or unsightly scar.
  7. Aspiration of tracheostomy tube fragments into the tracheobronchial tree

 

 

Mentioned below are some instruments used during the procedure. 

Cuffed tracheostomy tube:

  • It has an outer tube, an inner tube, and an obturator.
  • Presence of cuff prevents aspiration of pharyngeal secretions into the trachea and also prevents air-leak. 
  • Cuff should be deflated every 2 h for 5 min to prevent ischaemia and damage to the trachea and cartilage necrosis.

Uses:

  • Tracheostomy in an unconscious patient or in a patient on a respirator.

 

Tracheal dilator is used to keep the tracheal edges open after incision in the trachea so that tracheostomy tube can be easily inserted. 

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheostomy

High tracheostomy

  • Done through the 1st tracheal ring
  • An opening is made above the isthmus of the thyroid gland 
  • Done in case of malignancy of the larynx
  • Increased risk of perichondritis and subglottic stenosis

Mid tracheostomy

  • Done through the 2nd - 3rd rings
  • Most commonly done tracheostomy
  • Isthmus has to be retracted or divided

Low tracheostomy

  • Done through the 4th - 5th tracheal ring
  • Done below the isthmus
  • Done when the airway is blocked at an upper airway level
  • Risk of injuring the great vessels of the neck

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to you with complaints of noisy breathing. On performing direct laryngoscopy, subglottic stenosis is noted. Which grading system will you use to report the extent of the stenosis?
questions.solution:
Myer Cotton’s grading is used for subglottic stenosis.

It is the abnormal thickening of cricoid/fibrous tissue proliferation below cords. It causes the airway to narrow and presents with dyspnea, biphasic stridor and a normal cry. 

Diagnosis:

  • In full-term infants, subglottic diameter <4mm.
  • In premature infants, subglottic diameter <3mm.

The Myer Cotton’s grading system allows to stratify the stenosis and plan for treatment:

  • Grade 1: <50% stenosis
  • Grade 2: 51-70% stenosis
  • Grade 3: 71-99% stenosis
  • Grade 4: No lumen detected

Other options

Option A - Hyams grading is a predictive tool used in olfactory neuroblastoma.

Option B - House Brackmann grading is used as a facial nerve grading system.

Option D - Modified mallampati classification is used to assess difficult airway

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with complaints of dysphagia, fever, stridor, drooling, and muffled voice. The following image is seen on a lateral x-ray of the neck. What is the finding seen in the given radiograph?
questions.solution:
Thumb sign is seen on the given lateral view radiograph.

The above clinical features of a toxic looking child with high-grade fever, tachypnea, stridor, dysphagia with salivary drooling are suggestive of acute epiglottitis. Thumb sign on lateral X-ray of neck is pathognomonic for acute epiglottitis. 

Acute epiglottitis is an acute rapidly progressive confined to supraglottic structures i.e., epiglottis, aryepiglottic fold and arytenoids. It usually affects children of age 2-7 years. It has a potentially fulminating course of fever, sore throat, dyspnea, and rapidly progressing respiratory obstruction.

Management:

Indirect laryngoscopy shows edema and congestion of supraglottic structures. A lateral X-ray of the neck shows swollen epiglottis giving an appearance called the thumb sign.

Acute epiglottitis is a medical emergency due to sudden and unpredictable airway obstruction. The treatment includes the following:

  • Admission to ICU
  • Airway management - endotracheal intubation, tracheostomy for respiratory obstruction
  • Antibiotics - Ampicillin or third-generation cephalosporin is indicated in the treatment of acute epiglottitis along with airway management.
  • Dexamethasone may be given to reduce pharyngeal edema

Other options:

Option A: Steeple sign is seen in laryngotracheobronchitis.

 

Option C- Below image shows adenoid hypertrophy.

 

Option D- Omega shaped epiglottis is seen in laryngomalacia. This finding is seen in direct laryngoscopy.

Related Pearl: Acute stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Important differentials:

Condition  Findings
Croup

Non-toxic, viral prodrome, barking cough

X-ray neck shows steeple sign
Epiglottitis

Toxic child, drooling saliva

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign
Diphtheria Cervical lymph nodes (bull neck), dirty grey/ white membrane, and un-immunized
Foreign body aspiration Choking, decreased air entry, unilateral hyperinflation

questions.text: A patient with a parotid abscess is planned for incision and drainage (I & D). Which of the following practices will you avoid in this patient?

choices.text: Put an incision that is similar to parotidectomy
Blunt dissection of the pus pockets
Dissection parallel to the facial nerve branches
Wait for the swelling to become fluctuant before performing I & D

questions.solution:
In a case of a parotid abscess, one must never wait for fluctuation or pus point to occur. This is because the superficial layer of parotidomasseteric fascia is tense and the fluctuation will be apparent only in later stages.

A parotid abscess refers to an infection and pus formation in the parotid space. It is caused most commonly by Staphylococcus aureus. Post-surgical cases and debilitated patients with stasis of salivary flow are at risk of developing parotid abscesses.

Patients typically present with unilateral swelling, redness, induration, and tenderness over the parotid gland and angle of the mandible. Dehydration and fever are also present. Diagnosis is by ultrasonography or a CT scan. Multiple small loculi of pus are seen in the parenchyma. Aspiration of abscess can be done to determine the culture and sensitivity of the infective agent. 

Correction of dehydration, improving oral hygiene and promoting salivary flow. Intravenous antibiotics are also used in treatment. 

Surgical drainage under local or general anesthesia is carried out by a preauricular incision as employed for parotidectomy. A skin flap is raised to expose the surface of the gland, and the abscess or abscesses are bluntly opened working parallel to the branches of the VIIth nerve. The skin incision is loosely approximated over a drain and allowed to heal by secondary intention.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy with recurrent attacks of tonsillitis and speech difficulties was posted for a tonsillectomy procedure. Which of the following position is used in this surgery?
questions.solution:
Rose position is used in tonsillectomy surgery. 

In Rose's position, the patient is supine, with their head extended. A rubber ring is placed under the head to stabilize it and a pillow is placed under the shoulders to extend the head. Rose's position is also used in adenoidectomy and tracheostomy.

 

Indications of tonsillectomy are:

  • Recurrent episodes of acute tonsillitis – most common indication
  • Febrile seizures due to fever in tonsillitis
  • Peritonsillar abscess (quinsy) - recurrent episodes in adults and a single episode in children
  • Hypertrophy of tonsils causing airway obstruction, difficulty in deglutition, interference with speech
  • Unilateral enlargement of tonsil with suspicion of malignancy
  • Chronic tonsillitis with bad taste or halitosis which is unresponsive to medical treatment (relative indication)
  • As a part of the surgical management of sleep apnea syndrome, glossopharyngeal neuralgia, and Eagle's syndrome.

Contraindications for tonsillectomy:

  • Haemoglobin level less than 10 g%.
  • Presence of acute infection in upper respiratory tract, even acute tonsillitis. Bleeding is more in the presence of acute infection.
  • Children under 3 years of age. They are poor surgical risks.
  • Overt or submucous cleft palate.
  • Bleeding disorders, e.g. leukaemia, purpura, aplastic anaemia or haemophilia.
  • At the time of the epidemic of polio.
  • Uncontrolled systemic disease, e.g. diabetes, cardiac disease, hypertension or asthma.
  • Tonsillectomy is avoided during the period of menses.

Other options:

Option A: The sniffing position involves flexion of the neck on the body and extension of the head on the neck which is done during tracheal intubation.

Option B: Semi fowler position is lying supine incline at an angle of 30 - 45 degrees. This position is used for patients who have cardiac or respiratory conditions, and for patients with a nasogastric tube. 

Option C: Reverse Trendelenburg position is lying flat with head 15 - 30 degrees higher than the feet. This position is used in ocular and ENT surgeries like minimally invasive cataract surgery and rhinoplasty.

The below image shows the various surgical positions and the procedure they are used in:

questions.text: Identify the given instrument.
questions.solution:
The image shows a laryngeal mirror which is identified by its straight shaft without any bends with a mirror at the end.

Indirect Laryngoscopy is done by the use of a laryngeal mirror.

The patient is seated straight opposite the examiner, with the head and chest leaning slightly towards him. He is asked to protrude his tongue which is wrapped in gauze for protection from any inadvertent injury. The tongue is held by the examiner between the thumb and middle finger.

The laryngeal mirror (size 4–6) is introduced into the mouth and held firmly against the uvula and soft palate. It should be warmed and tested on the back of the hand before introduction. Light is focused on the laryngeal mirror and the patient is asked to breathe quietly. Movements of both cords are seen and compared by asking the patient to take deep inspiration (abduction of cords), say “Aa” (adduction of cords), and “Eee” (for adduction and tension).

Structures seen on indirect laryngoscopy (in order) are:

  • The base of the tongue (posterior one-third of the tongue)
  • Vallecula
  • Median and lateral glossoepiglottic folds
  • Epiglottis
  • Pharyngoepiglottic folds
  • Aryepiglottic folds
  • Arytenoids
  • False vocal cords
  • True vocal cords

Other options:

Options A and C: St. Clair Thompson mirror is the other name for the Postnasal/ posterior rhinoscopy mirror. It has two bends in the shaft and is bayonet shaped.

Option D: A double hook retractor is used to retract soft tissues during surgery.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy with nasal obstruction, nasal discharge,  sinusitis, and chronic suppurative otitis media is scheduled for adenoidectomy. Which of the following is a contraindication for this procedure?
questions.solution:
The presence of a cleft palate is a contraindication for adenoidectomy. 

Performing an adenoidectomy in a patient with a cleft palate can lead to velopharyngeal insufficiency, a disorder of the velopharyngeal valve. The function of this valve is to separate the oral and nasal cavities during actions like speaking, swallowing, vomiting, blowing, and sucking.

Velopharyngeal insufficiency leads to reduced speech intelligence as well as social and functional impairment. Patients have hypernasal speech, compensatory facial grimacing, and misarticulation.  

Indications for adenoidectomy include: 

  1. Symptomatic adenoid hypertrophy
  2. Recurrent sinusitis (Option A)
  3. Chronic otitis media (Option B) 
  4. Chronic suppurative otitis media and recurrent ear discharge
  5. Dental malocclusion (Option D) occurring due to a low-positioned tongue, and separated lips. 

Contraindications of adenoidectomy include: 

  1. Cleft palate or submucous palate
  2. Hemorrhagic diathesis
  3. Acute infection of the upper respiratory tract 

Adenoidectomy is performed under general anesthesia in Rose's position. Here the patient is supine with the head extended by using a pillow under the shoulders. The head is stabilized with a rubber ring and hyperextension of the neck should be avoided. 

A Boyle - Davis mouth gag is inserted after examining the nasopharynx. An adenoid curette with a guard is introduced into the nasopharynx to engage the adenoids. The adenoid tissue is shaved off with gentle sweeping movements with smaller curettes used to remove lateral masses while avoiding the eustachian tubes. Hemostasis is achieved by packing the area and electrocoagulation. Persistent bleeding can be treated with a postnasal pack. 

Complications of adenoidectomy include: 

  • Hemorrhage
  • Injury to the eustachian tube opening
  • Injury to pharyngeal musculature and vertebrae due to hyperextension of the neck and pressure of the curette
  • Griesel syndrome: neck pain and torticollis due to spasm of paraspinal muscles or atlantoaxial dislocation
  • Velopharyngeal insufficiency
  • Nasopharyngeal stenosis
  • Recurrence.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy was brought with loud, raspy, and noisy breathing. His mother also says that his voice has become hoarse over the past 3-4 months. He was born at term through an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. The fiberoptic laryngoscopy image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is suggestive of laryngeal papilloma or recurrent respiratory papillomatosis.

It is the most common benign neoplasm of the larynx in children. It is caused by human papilloma DNA virus (HPV) types 6 and 11. Squamous papillomas can be seen in children, juvenile papillomatosis (as in this case), and in adults, adult-onset papilloma. 

It is thought that the patients acquire this condition from their mothers who had vaginal human papillomavirus infection during birth. It is usually seen in the supraglottic and glottic regions. Less commonly, the subglottis, trachea, and bronchi may be involved.

Clinically, the patient is typically a young child 3-5 years of age. They may present with hoarseness of voice, stridor, and breathing difficulty. The disease recurs requiring repeated surgical and medical management throughout childhood. Rarely, they may undergo malignant change. 

It is diagnosed using flexible fiberoptic laryngoscopy and may later be confirmed by direct laryngoscopy or rigid bronchoscopy and biopsy.

Treatment of recurrent respiratory papillomatosis:

  • Surgical management with excision using a CO2 laser
  • Medical management using interferon-alpha has been tried as an adjuvant, but it is associated with significant side effects 

The adult-onset version is usually less severe and does not recur after surgical removal. It affects males more than females and presents between the ages of 30-50 years. 

Other options: 

Option A - Laryngomalacia is a congenital condition of the larynx that manifests at birth and disappears by the age of 2 years. Babies present with stridor on crying that relieves in the prone position. 

The following image shows the omega-shaped epiglottis of laryngomalacia:

 

Option B - Reinke's edema is a collection of fluid in the subepithelial space of Reinke. It generally occurs in patients with vocal abuse or smoking. The vocal cords will show diffuse, symmetrical swelling. 

The following image shows Reinke's edema:

 

Option C - Vocal cord nodules occur at the junction of the anterior one-third and posterior two-thirds of the vocal cords. This occurs due to vocal trauma that happens when the patient speaks in low tones or high intensities for prolonged periods.
